content: Negotiating parties of the proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) have until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA would enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. Mexico signed the ACTA on July 11, 2012, requiring ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Union, Mexico, and Switzerland expressed support for the Agreement. The final version of the agreement text was released in May 2011 after nearly three years of negotiations. The ACTA is aimed at combating intellectual property rights infringement. The ACTA, signed by several countries in 2011, aims to combat intellectual property rights infringement, focusing on trademarks and copyrights enforcement. It builds on the standards set by the WTO TRIPS Agreement and addresses emerging IPR issues, particularly in the digital environment. The agreement establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, including civil enforcement, border measures, and criminal enforcement for willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy. The ACTA negotiation concluded in October 2010, with countries having until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. All negotiating parties, except Mexico and Switzerland, have signed the agreement. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, international cooperation, and enhanced measures. Key provisions include the nature and scope of the agreement, relationship to existing agreements, flexibility for Parties to implement more extensive IPR enforcement, and determine appropriate methods of implementation. The ACTA allows Parties to implement more extensive IPR enforcement, with flexibility in how provisions are implemented. It notes that TRIPS Agreement principles apply, and does not require obligations for intellectual property not protected under domestic laws. The legal framework chapter includes obligations for enforcement, civil, border, criminal, and digital environment enforcement, emphasizing effective action without trade barriers. The obligations section of the ACTA commits Parties to effective IPR enforcement action, ensuring expeditious and deterrent remedies while avoiding trade barriers. It also requires proportionality in enforcement measures and penalties. Civil enforcement provisions mandate the availability of judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions and damages for right holders. The civil enforcement section of the ACTA mandates judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and attorney's fees. It also allows for the destruction of infringing goods and provisional measures like seizures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and undisclosed information from this section. The border measures section of the ACTA focuses on effective enforcement of intellectual property rights at borders without hindering legitimate trade. It includes provisions for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods and allows right holders to request such actions. The ACTA allows authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods and detain them, with right holders able to request such actions. It also mandates procedures for determining IPR infringement, authorizes the destruction of infringing goods, and imposes penalties. Criminal enforcement is required for willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale. The ACTA mandates penalties, including imprisonment and fines, for willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale. It requires authorities to seize suspected counterfeit goods, order forfeiture or destruction of infringing goods and related materials, and seize assets derived from infringing activities. The ACTA mandates penalties for trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy on a commercial scale, including imprisonment and fines. The digital enforcement section focuses on enforcement procedures for copyright and related rights over digital networks, ensuring effective action against infringement while preserving freedom of expression, fair process, and privacy. Parties may disclose identifying information related to alleged infringement and provide legal protection against circumvention of technological measures. The enforcement practices chapter of ACTA focuses on methods used by Parties to apply IPR enforcement laws, promoting development of expertise, data collection, and sharing information to combat infringement risks at the border. The international cooperation chapter of ACTA emphasizes promoting transparency in IPR enforcement systems, raising public awareness on respecting IPR, and considering environmental factors in the destruction of infringing goods. It also encourages cooperation among competent authorities to address challenges in cross-border trade of counterfeit and pirated products. The institutional arrangement chapter of ACTA establishes an ACTA Committee to review implementation, proposed amendments, and terms of accession.
